<s> these were farewell visits for life and of course not a little interesting .... <\s>
<s> ever faithfully yours w <\s>
<s> in the summer of 1842 wordsworth resigned his office of stamp distributor not however on a retiring pension as has been sometimes asserted <\s>
<s> in a letter dated march 2 1840 and addressed to lord morpeth he says i never did seek or accept a pension from the present or any other administration directly or indirectly <\s>
<s> but the duties and also the emoluments of the distributorship were transferred to his son william who had for some time acted as his deputy at carlisle 186 127 <\s>
<s> the master of trinity <\s>
<s> letter to a nephew <\s>
<s> my dear c your father left us yesterday having been just a week under our roof <\s>
<s> the weather was favourable and he seemed to enjoy himself much <\s>
<s> his muscular strength as proved by the walks we took together is great <\s>
<s> one day we were nearly four hours on foot without resting and he did not appear in the least fatigued <\s>
<s> we all thought him looking well and his mind appears as active as ever <\s>
<s> it was a great delight to us to see him here <\s>
<s> he was anxious to see charles he will reach winchester this afternoon i hope without injury <\s>
<s> of alston's portrait of coleridge <\s>
<s> from his own modest merits and his long connection with mr <\s>
<s> coleridge and with my early bristol remembrances he was to me an interesting person <\s>
<s> his desire to have my address must have risen i think from a wish to communicate with me upon the subject of mr <\s>
<s> alston's valuable portrait of coleridge <\s>
<s> pray tell me what has or is likely to become of it <\s>
<s> i care comparatively little about the matter provided due care has been taken for its preservation and in his native country <\s>
<s> it would be a sad pity if the late owner's intention of sending it to america be fulfilled <\s>
<s> it is the only likeness of the great original that ever gave me the least pleasure and it is in fact most happily executed as every one who has a distinct remembrance of what c <\s>
<s> was at that time must with delight acknowledge and would be glad to certify 188 129 <\s>
<s> the papers will have informed you before you receive this of poor dear southey's decease <\s>
<s> he died yesterday morning about nine o'clock <\s>
<s> some little time since he was seized with typhus fever but he passed away without any outward signs of pain as gently as possible <\s>
<s> we are of course not without sadness upon the occasion notwithstanding there has been for years cause why all who knew and loved him should wish for his deliverance 189 130 <\s>
<s> tropical scenery grace darling southey c letter to lieutenant general sir wm <\s>
<s> gomm 190 187 memoirs ii <\s>
<s> 188 extract of letter to john peace esq dec <\s>
<s> 12 1842 ibid ii <\s>
<s> 189 extract of letter to nephew march 22 1843 ibid ii <\s>
<s> 190 the venerable and illustrious soldier has only very recently died <\s>
<s> i am rather afraid i own of any attempt of this kind notwithstanding my high opinion of his ability but if he keeps in his present mind which i doubt it will be in vain to oppose his inclination <\s>
<s> he is a great enthusiast possessed also of a most active intellect but he wants that submissive and steady good sense which is absolutely necessary for the adequate development of power in that art to which he is attached <\s>
<s> as i am on the subject of painting it may be worth while to add that pickersgill came down last summer to paint a portrait of me for sir robert peel's gallery at drayton manor <\s>
<s> it was generally thought here that this work was more successful than the one he painted some years ago for st <\s>
<s> john's college at the request of the master and fellows 177 177 memoirs ii <\s>
<s> of peace's apology for cathedrals i have no especial reason for writing at this moment of time but i have long wished to thank you for the apology for cathedrals which i have learned is from your pen <\s>
<s> the little work does you great credit it is full of that wisdom which the heart and imagination alone could adequately supply for such a subject and is moreover very pleasingly diversified by styles of treatment all good in their kind <\s>
<s> i need add no more than that i entirely concur in the views you take but what avails it <\s>
<s> the mischief is done and they who have been most prominent in setting it on foot will have to repent of their narrow comprehension which however is no satisfaction to us who from the first foresaw the evil tendency of the measure 178 178 extract of letter to john peace esq jan <\s>
<s> 19 1841 memoirs ii <\s>
<s> of the task of cowper and shenstone <\s>
<s> though i can make but little use of my eyes in writing or reading i have lately been reading cowper's task aloud and in so doing was tempted to look over the parallelisms for which mr <\s>
<s> southey was in his edition indebted to you <\s>
<s> knowing how comprehensive your acquaintance with poetry is i was rather surprised that you did not notice the identity of the thought and accompanying illustrations of it in a passage of shenstone's ode upon rural elegance compared with one in the task where cowper speaks of the inextinguishable love of the country as manifested by the inhabitants of cities in their culture of plants and flowers where the want of air cleanliness and light is so unfavourable to their growth and beauty <\s>
<s> the germ of the main thought is to be found in horace nempe inter varias nutritur sylva columnas laudaturque domus longos quae prospicit agros naturam expellas furc ?? tamen usque recurret <\s>
<s> pray write to me soon <\s>
<s> ever my dear friend faithfully your obliged wm <\s>
<s> letter to john peace esq <\s>
<s> 12 north parade bath april 19 <\s>
<s> peace here i am and have been since last wednesday evening <\s>
<s> i came down the wye and passed through bristol but arriving there at the moment the railway train was about to set off and being in the company of four ladies miss fenwick and mrs <\s>
<s> wordsworth and my daughter and niece i had not a moment to spare so could not call on you my good friend which i truly regretted <\s>
<s> pray spare an hour or two to come here and then we can fix a day when along with my daughter i can visit bristol see you mr <\s>
<s> all unite in kindest regards <\s>
<s> peace this morning my dear daughter was married in st <\s>
<s> james's in this place <\s>
<s> tomorrow we leave bath for wells and thence to the old haunts of mr <\s>
<s> coleridge and myself and dear sister about alfoxden <\s>
<s> w 181 179 extract of letter to john peace esq january 19 1841 memoirs ii <\s>
<s> 180 memoirs ii 377 <\s>
<s> letters to his brother <\s>
<s> wordsworth master of trinity college cambridge <\s>
<s> my dear brother your affectionate and generous kindness to your i trust deserving niece has quite overpowered me and her mother to whom i could not forbear communicating the contents of your letter <\s>
<s> the above relates to an act of kindness which the late master of trinity had the happiness of performing on the occasion of dora wordsworth's marriage <\s>
<s> the following refers to a serious accident which occurred to him at cambridge by a fall from his horse feb <\s>
<s> my dear brother the good accounts which we receive from time to time of your progress towards perfect recovery from your late severe accident embolden me to congratulate you in my own name and the whole of my family <\s>
<s> it remains now for us to join heartily as we all do in expressing a wish that being convalescent you would not be tempted to over exert yourself <\s>
<s> i need scarcely add that we all unite with you and your sons with susan and your other relations and all your friends in fervent thanks to almighty god for his goodness in preserving you <\s>
<s> as a brother i feel deeply and regarding your life as most valuable to the community i the more rejoice in the prospect of your life being prolonged <\s>
<s> believe me my dear brother most affectionately yours wm <\s>
<s> wordsworth 182 182 memoirs ii <\s>
<s> episcopal church of america emerson and carlyle <\s>
<s> rydal mount ambleside aug <\s>
<s> reed i have lately had the pleasure of seeing both in london and at my own house the bishop of new jersey <\s>
<s> he is a man of no ordinary powers of mind and attainments of warm feelings and sincere piety <\s>
<s> indeed i never saw a person of your country which is remarkable for cordiality whose manner was so thoroughly cordial <\s>
<s> he had been greatly delighted with his reception in england and what he had seen of it both in art and nature <\s>
<s> by the by i heard him preach an excellent sermon in london <\s>
<s> i believe this privilege is of modern date <\s>
<s> the bishop has furnished me with his funeral sermon upon bishop white to assist me in fulfilling a request which you first made to me viz <\s>
<s> that i would add a sonnet to my ecclesiastical series upon the union of the two episcopal churches of england and america 183 i will endeavour to do so when i have more leisure than at present this being the season when our beautiful region attracts many strangers who take up much of my time <\s>
<s> do you know miss peabody of boston <\s>
<s> she has just sent me with the highest eulogy certain essays of mr <\s>
<s> carlyle and he appear to be what the french used to call esprits forts though the french idols showed their spirit after a somewhat different fashion <\s>
<s> our two present philosophes who have taken a language which they suppose to be english for their vehicle are verily par nobile fratrum and it is a pity that the weakness of our age has not left them exclusively to this appropriate reward mutual admiration <\s>
<s> where is the thing which now passes for philosophy at boston to stop <\s>
<s> ever faithfully yours wm <\s>
<s> wordsworth 184 183 dr <\s>
<s> seabury was consecrated bishop of connecticut by scottish bishops at aberdeen on 14th november 1784 <\s>
<s> provoost were consecrated bishops of new york and pennsylvania at lambeth 4th february 1787 <\s>
<s> letter to john peace esq <\s>
<s> my dear peace mrs <\s>
<s> we were three months and as many weeks absent before we reached our own home again <\s>
<s> we made a very agreeable tour in devonshire going by exeter to plymouth and returning along the coast by salisbury and winchester to london <\s>
<s> in london and its neighbourhood we stayed not quite a month <\s>
<s> during this tour we visited my old haunts at and about alfoxden and nethertowey and at coleorton where we stayed several days <\s>
<s> these were farewell visits for life and of course not a little interesting .... <\s>
<s> ever faithfully yours w <\s>
<s> in the summer of 1842 wordsworth resigned his office of stamp distributor not however on a retiring pension as has been sometimes asserted <\s>
<s> in a letter dated march 2 1840 and addressed to lord morpeth he says i never did seek or accept a pension from the present or any other administration directly or indirectly <\s>
<s> but the duties and also the emoluments of the distributorship were transferred to his son william who had for some time acted as his deputy at carlisle 186 127 <\s>
<s> the master of trinity <\s>
<s> letter to a nephew <\s>
<s> my dear c your father left us yesterday having been just a week under our roof <\s>
<s> the weather was favourable and he seemed to enjoy himself much <\s>
<s> his muscular strength as proved by the walks we took together is great <\s>
<s> one day we were nearly four hours on foot without resting and he did not appear in the least fatigued <\s>
<s> we all thought him looking well and his mind appears as active as ever <\s>
<s> it was a great delight to us to see him here <\s>
<s> he was anxious to see charles he will reach winchester this afternoon i hope without injury <\s>
<s> of alston's portrait of coleridge <\s>
<s> from his own modest merits and his long connection with mr <\s>
<s> coleridge and with my early bristol remembrances he was to me an interesting person <\s>
<s> his desire to have my address must have risen i think from a wish to communicate with me upon the subject of mr <\s>
<s> alston's valuable portrait of coleridge <\s>
<s> pray tell me what has or is likely to become of it <\s>
<s> i care comparatively little about the matter provided due care has been taken for its preservation and in his native country <\s>
<s> it would be a sad pity if the late owner's intention of sending it to america be fulfilled <\s>
<s> it is the only likeness of the great original that ever gave me the least pleasure and it is in fact most happily executed as every one who has a distinct remembrance of what c <\s>
<s> was at that time must with delight acknowledge and would be glad to certify 188 129 <\s>
<s> the papers will have informed you before you receive this of poor dear southey's decease <\s>
<s> he died yesterday morning about nine o'clock <\s>
<s> some little time since he was seized with typhus fever but he passed away without any outward signs of pain as gently as possible <\s>
<s> we are of course not without sadness upon the occasion notwithstanding there has been for years cause why all who knew and loved him should wish for his deliverance 189 130 <\s>

<s> as a brother i feel deeply and regarding your life as most valuable to the community i the more rejoice in the prospect of your life being prolonged <\s>

<s> wordsworth 182 182 memoirs ii <\s>
<s> episcopal church of america emerson and carlyle <\s>
<s> rydal mount ambleside aug <\s>
<s> reed i have lately had the pleasure of seeing both in london and at my own house the bishop of new jersey <\s>
<s> he is a man of no ordinary powers of mind and attainments of warm feelings and sincere piety <\s>
<s> indeed i never saw a person of your country which is remarkable for cordiality whose manner was so thoroughly cordial <\s>
<s> he had been greatly delighted with his reception in england and what he had seen of it both in art and nature <\s>
<s> by the by i heard him preach an excellent sermon in london <\s>
<s> i believe this privilege is of modern date <\s>
<s> the bishop has furnished me with his funeral sermon upon bishop white to assist me in fulfilling a request which you first made to me viz <\s>
<s> that i would add a sonnet to my ecclesiastical series upon the union of the two episcopal churches of england and america 183 i will endeavour to do so when i have more leisure than at present this being the season when our beautiful region attracts many strangers who take up much of my time <\s>
<s> do you know miss peabody of boston <\s>
<s> she has just sent me with the highest eulogy certain essays of mr <\s>
<s> carlyle and he appear to be what the french used to call esprits forts though the french idols showed their spirit after a somewhat different fashion <\s>
<s> our two present philosophes who have taken a language which they suppose to be english for their vehicle are verily par nobile fratrum and it is a pity that the weakness of our age has not left them exclusively to this appropriate reward mutual admiration <\s>
<s> where is the thing which now passes for philosophy at boston to stop <\s>
<s> ever faithfully yours wm <\s>
<s> wordsworth 184 183 dr <\s>
<s> seabury was consecrated bishop of connecticut by scottish bishops at aberdeen on 14th november 1784 <\s>
<s> provoost were consecrated bishops of new york and pennsylvania at lambeth 4th february 1787 <\s>
<s> letter to john peace esq <\s>
<s> my dear peace mrs <\s>
<s> we were three months and as many weeks absent before we reached our own home again <\s>
<s> we made a very agreeable tour in devonshire going by exeter to plymouth and returning along the coast by salisbury and winchester to london <\s>
<s> in london and its neighbourhood we stayed not quite a month <\s>
<s> during this tour we visited my old haunts at and about alfoxden and nethertowey and at coleorton where we stayed several days <\s>
<s> these were farewell visits for life and of course not a little interesting .... <\s>
<s> ever faithfully yours w <\s>
<s> in the summer of 1842 wordsworth resigned his office of stamp distributor not however on a retiring pension as has been sometimes asserted <\s>
<s> in a letter dated march 2 1840 and addressed to lord morpeth he says i never did seek or accept a pension from the present or any other administration directly or indirectly <\s>
<s> but the duties and also the emoluments of the distributorship were transferred to his son william who had for some time acted as his deputy at carlisle 186 127 <\s>
<s> the master of trinity <\s>
<s> letter to a nephew <\s>
<s> my dear c your father left us yesterday having been just a week under our roof <\s>
<s> the weather was favourable and he seemed to enjoy himself much <\s>
<s> his muscular strength as proved by the walks we took together is great <\s>
<s> one day we were nearly four hours on foot without resting and he did not appear in the least fatigued <\s>
<s> we all thought him looking well and his mind appears as active as ever <\s>
<s> it was a great delight to us to see him here <\s>
<s> he was anxious to see charles he will reach winchester this afternoon i hope without injury <\s>
<s> of alston's portrait of coleridge <\s>
<s> from his own modest merits and his long connection with mr <\s>
<s> coleridge and with my early bristol remembrances he was to me an interesting person <\s>
<s> his desire to have my address must have risen i think from a wish to communicate with me upon the subject of mr <\s>
<s> alston's valuable portrait of coleridge <\s>
<s> pray tell me what has or is likely to become of it <\s>
<s> i care comparatively little about the matter provided due care has been taken for its preservation and in his native country <\s>
<s> it would be a sad pity if the late owner's intention of sending it to america be fulfilled <\s>
<s> it is the only likeness of the great original that ever gave me the least pleasure and it is in fact most happily executed as every one who has a distinct remembrance of what c <\s>
<s> was at that time must with delight acknowledge and would be glad to certify 188 129 <\s>
<s> the papers will have informed you before you receive this of poor dear southey's decease <\s>
<s> he died yesterday morning about nine o'clock <\s>
<s> some little time since he was seized with typhus fever but he passed away without any outward signs of pain as gently as possible <\s>
<s> we are of course not without sadness upon the occasion notwithstanding there has been for years cause why all who knew and loved him should wish for his deliverance 189 130 <\s>
<s> tropical scenery grace darling southey c letter to lieutenant general sir wm <\s>
<s> gomm 190 187 memoirs ii <\s>
<s> 188 extract of letter to john peace esq dec <\s>
<s> 12 1842 ibid ii <\s>
<s> 189 extract of letter to nephew march 22 1843 ibid ii <\s>
<s> 190 the venerable and illustrious soldier has only very recently died <\s>
<s> i am rather afraid i own of any attempt of this kind notwithstanding my high opinion of his ability but if he keeps in his present mind which i doubt it will be in vain to oppose his inclination <\s>
<s> he is a great enthusiast possessed also of a most active intellect but he wants that submissive and steady good sense which is absolutely necessary for the adequate development of power in that art to which he is attached <\s>
<s> as i am on the subject of painting it may be worth while to add that pickersgill came down last summer to paint a portrait of me for sir robert peel's gallery at drayton manor <\s>
<s> it was generally thought here that this work was more successful than the one he painted some years ago for st <\s>
<s> john's college at the request of the master and fellows 177 177 memoirs ii <\s>
<s> of peace's apology for cathedrals i have no especial reason for writing at this moment of time but i have long wished to thank you for the apology for cathedrals which i have learned is from your pen <\s>
<s> the little work does you great credit it is full of that wisdom which the heart and imagination alone could adequately supply for such a subject and is moreover very pleasingly diversified by styles of treatment all good in their kind <\s>
<s> i need add no more than that i entirely concur in the views you take but what avails it <\s>
<s> the mischief is done and they who have been most prominent in setting it on foot will have to repent of their narrow comprehension which however is no satisfaction to us who from the first foresaw the evil tendency of the measure 178 178 extract of letter to john peace esq jan <\s>
<s> 19 1841 memoirs ii <\s>
<s> of the task of cowper and shenstone <\s>
<s> though i can make but little use of my eyes in writing or reading i have lately been reading cowper's task aloud and in so doing was tempted to look over the parallelisms for which mr <\s>
<s> southey was in his edition indebted to you <\s>
<s> knowing how comprehensive your acquaintance with poetry is i was rather surprised that you did not notice the identity of the thought and accompanying illustrations of it in a passage of shenstone's ode upon rural elegance compared with one in the task where cowper speaks of the inextinguishable love of the country as manifested by the inhabitants of cities in their culture of plants and flowers where the want of air cleanliness and light is so unfavourable to their growth and beauty <\s>
<s> the germ of the main thought is to be found in horace nempe inter varias nutritur sylva columnas laudaturque domus longos quae prospicit agros naturam expellas furc ?? tamen usque recurret <\s>
<s> pray write to me soon <\s>
<s> ever my dear friend faithfully your obliged wm <\s>
<s> letter to john peace esq <\s>
<s> 12 north parade bath april 19 <\s>
<s> peace here i am and have been since last wednesday evening <\s>
<s> i came down the wye and passed through bristol but arriving there at the moment the railway train was about to set off and being in the company of four ladies miss fenwick and mrs <\s>
<s> wordsworth and my daughter and niece i had not a moment to spare so could not call on you my good friend which i truly regretted <\s>
<s> pray spare an hour or two to come here and then we can fix a day when along with my daughter i can visit bristol see you mr <\s>
<s> all unite in kindest regards <\s>
<s> peace this morning my dear daughter was married in st <\s>
<s> james's in this place <\s>
<s> tomorrow we leave bath for wells and thence to the old haunts of mr <\s>
<s> coleridge and myself and dear sister about alfoxden <\s>
<s> w 181 179 extract of letter to john peace esq january 19 1841 memoirs ii <\s>
<s> 180 memoirs ii 377 <\s>
<s> letters to his brother <\s>
<s> wordsworth master of trinity college cambridge <\s>
<s> my dear brother your affectionate and generous kindness to your i trust deserving niece has quite overpowered me and her mother to whom i could not forbear communicating the contents of your letter <\s>
<s> the above relates to an act of kindness which the late master of trinity had the happiness of performing on the occasion of dora wordsworth's marriage <\s>
<s> the following refers to a serious accident which occurred to him at cambridge by a fall from his horse feb <\s>
<s> my dear brother the good accounts which we receive from time to time of your progress towards perfect recovery from your late severe accident embolden me to congratulate you in my own name and the whole of my family <\s>
<s> it remains now for us to join heartily as we all do in expressing a wish that being convalescent you would not be tempted to over exert yourself <\s>
<s> i need scarcely add that we all unite with you and your sons with susan and your other relations and all your friends in fervent thanks to almighty god for his goodness in preserving you <\s>
<s> as a brother i feel deeply and regarding your life as most valuable to the community i the more rejoice in the prospect of your life being prolonged <\s>
<s> believe me my dear brother most affectionately yours wm <\s>
<s> wordsworth 182 182 memoirs ii <\s>
<s> episcopal church of america emerson and carlyle <\s>
<s> rydal mount ambleside aug <\s>
<s> reed i have lately had the pleasure of seeing both in london and at my own house the bishop of new jersey <\s>
<s> he is a man of no ordinary powers of mind and attainments of warm feelings and sincere piety <\s>
<s> indeed i never saw a person of your country which is remarkable for cordiality whose manner was so thoroughly cordial <\s>
<s> he had been greatly delighted with his reception in england and what he had seen of it both in art and nature <\s>
<s> by the by i heard him preach an excellent sermon in london <\s>
<s> i believe this privilege is of modern date <\s>
<s> the bishop has furnished me with his funeral sermon upon bishop white to assist me in fulfilling a request which you first made to me viz <\s>
<s> that i would add a sonnet to my ecclesiastical series upon the union of the two episcopal churches of england and america 183 i will endeavour to do so when i have more leisure than at present this being the season when our beautiful region attracts many strangers who take up much of my time <\s>
<s> do you know miss peabody of boston <\s>
<s> she has just sent me with the highest eulogy certain essays of mr <\s>
<s> carlyle and he appear to be what the french used to call esprits forts though the french idols showed their spirit after a somewhat different fashion <\s>
<s> our two present philosophes who have taken a language which they suppose to be english for their vehicle are verily par nobile fratrum and it is a pity that the weakness of our age has not left them exclusively to this appropriate reward mutual admiration <\s>
<s> where is the thing which now passes for philosophy at boston to stop <\s>

<s> though i can make but little use of my eyes in writing or reading i have lately been reading cowper's task aloud and in so doing was tempted to look over the parallelisms for which mr <\s>
<s> southey was in his edition indebted to you <\s>
<s> knowing how comprehensive your acquaintance with poetry is i was rather surprised that you did not notice the identity of the thought and accompanying illustrations of it in a passage of shenstone's ode upon rural elegance compared with one in the task where cowper speaks of the inextinguishable love of the country as manifested by the inhabitants of cities in their culture of plants and flowers where the want of air cleanliness and light is so unfavourable to their growth and beauty <\s>
<s> the germ of the main thought is to be found in horace nempe inter varias nutritur sylva columnas laudaturque domus longos quae prospicit agros naturam expellas furc ?? tamen usque recurret <\s>
<s> pray write to me soon <\s>
<s> ever my dear friend faithfully your obliged wm <\s>
<s> letter to john peace esq <\s>
<s> 12 north parade bath april 19 <\s>
<s> peace here i am and have been since last wednesday evening <\s>
<s> i came down the wye and passed through bristol but arriving there at the moment the railway train was about to set off and being in the company of four ladies miss fenwick and mrs <\s>
<s> wordsworth and my daughter and niece i had not a moment to spare so could not call on you my good friend which i truly regretted <\s>
<s> pray spare an hour or two to come here and then we can fix a day when along with my daughter i can visit bristol see you mr <\s>
<s> all unite in kindest regards <\s>
<s> peace this morning my dear daughter was married in st <\s>
<s> james's in this place <\s>
<s> tomorrow we leave bath for wells and thence to the old haunts of mr <\s>
<s> coleridge and myself and dear sister about alfoxden <\s>
<s> w 181 179 extract of letter to john peace esq january 19 1841 memoirs ii <\s>
<s> 180 memoirs ii 377 <\s>
<s> letters to his brother <\s>
<s> wordsworth master of trinity college cambridge <\s>
<s> my dear brother your affectionate and generous kindness to your i trust deserving niece has quite overpowered me and her mother to whom i could not forbear communicating the contents of your letter <\s>
<s> the above relates to an act of kindness which the late master of trinity had the happiness of performing on the occasion of dora wordsworth's marriage <\s>
<s> the following refers to a serious accident which occurred to him at cambridge by a fall from his horse feb <\s>
<s> my dear brother the good accounts which we receive from time to time of your progress towards perfect recovery from your late severe accident embolden me to congratulate you in my own name and the whole of my family <\s>
<s> it remains now for us to join heartily as we all do in expressing a wish that being convalescent you would not be tempted to over exert yourself <\s>
<s> i need scarcely add that we all unite with you and your sons with susan and your other relations and all your friends in fervent thanks to almighty god for his goodness in preserving you <\s>
<s> as a brother i feel deeply and regarding your life as most valuable to the community i the more rejoice in the prospect of your life being prolonged <\s>
<s> believe me my dear brother most affectionately yours wm <\s>
<s> wordsworth 182 182 memoirs ii <\s>
<s> episcopal church of america emerson and carlyle <\s>
<s> rydal mount ambleside aug <\s>
<s> reed i have lately had the pleasure of seeing both in london and at my own house the bishop of new jersey <\s>
<s> he is a man of no ordinary powers of mind and attainments of warm feelings and sincere piety <\s>
<s> indeed i never saw a person of your country which is remarkable for cordiality whose manner was so thoroughly cordial <\s>
<s> he had been greatly delighted with his reception in england and what he had seen of it both in art and nature <\s>
<s> by the by i heard him preach an excellent sermon in london <\s>
<s> i believe this privilege is of modern date <\s>
<s> the bishop has furnished me with his funeral sermon upon bishop white to assist me in fulfilling a request which you first made to me viz <\s>
<s> that i would add a sonnet to my ecclesiastical series upon the union of the two episcopal churches of england and america 183 i will endeavour to do so when i have more leisure than at present this being the season when our beautiful region attracts many strangers who take up much of my time <\s>
<s> do you know miss peabody of boston <\s>
<s> she has just sent me with the highest eulogy certain essays of mr <\s>
<s> carlyle and he appear to be what the french used to call esprits forts though the french idols showed their spirit after a somewhat different fashion <\s>
<s> our two present philosophes who have taken a language which they suppose to be english for their vehicle are verily par nobile fratrum and it is a pity that the weakness of our age has not left them exclusively to this appropriate reward mutual admiration <\s>
<s> where is the thing which now passes for philosophy at boston to stop <\s>
<s> ever faithfully yours wm <\s>
<s> wordsworth 184 183 dr <\s>
<s> seabury was consecrated bishop of connecticut by scottish bishops at aberdeen on 14th november 1784 <\s>
<s> provoost were consecrated bishops of new york and pennsylvania at lambeth 4th february 1787 <\s>
<s> letter to john peace esq <\s>
<s> my dear peace mrs <\s>
<s> we were three months and as many weeks absent before we reached our own home again <\s>
<s> we made a very agreeable tour in devonshire going by exeter to plymouth and returning along the coast by salisbury and winchester to london <\s>
<s> in london and its neighbourhood we stayed not quite a month <\s>
<s> during this tour we visited my old haunts at and about alfoxden and nethertowey and at coleorton where we stayed several days <\s>
<s> these were farewell visits for life and of course not a little interesting .... <\s>
<s> ever faithfully yours w <\s>
<s> in the summer of 1842 wordsworth resigned his office of stamp distributor not however on a retiring pension as has been sometimes asserted <\s>
<s> in a letter dated march 2 1840 and addressed to lord morpeth he says i never did seek or accept a pension from the present or any other administration directly or indirectly <\s>
<s> but the duties and also the emoluments of the distributorship were transferred to his son william who had for some time acted as his deputy at carlisle 186 127 <\s>
<s> the master of trinity <\s>
<s> letter to a nephew <\s>
<s> my dear c your father left us yesterday having been just a week under our roof <\s>
<s> the weather was favourable and he seemed to enjoy himself much <\s>
<s> his muscular strength as proved by the walks we took together is great <\s>
<s> one day we were nearly four hours on foot without resting and he did not appear in the least fatigued <\s>
<s> we all thought him looking well and his mind appears as active as ever <\s>
<s> it was a great delight to us to see him here <\s>
<s> he was anxious to see charles he will reach winchester this afternoon i hope without injury <\s>
<s> of alston's portrait of coleridge <\s>
<s> from his own modest merits and his long connection with mr <\s>
<s> coleridge and with my early bristol remembrances he was to me an interesting person <\s>
<s> his desire to have my address must have risen i think from a wish to communicate with me upon the subject of mr <\s>
<s> alston's valuable portrait of coleridge <\s>
<s> pray tell me what has or is likely to become of it <\s>
<s> i care comparatively little about the matter provided due care has been taken for its preservation and in his native country <\s>
<s> it would be a sad pity if the late owner's intention of sending it to america be fulfilled <\s>
<s> it is the only likeness of the great original that ever gave me the least pleasure and it is in fact most happily executed as every one who has a distinct remembrance of what c <\s>
<s> was at that time must with delight acknowledge and would be glad to certify 188 129 <\s>
<s> the papers will have informed you before you receive this of poor dear southey's decease <\s>
<s> he died yesterday morning about nine o'clock <\s>
<s> some little time since he was seized with typhus fever but he passed away without any outward signs of pain as gently as possible <\s>
<s> we are of course not without sadness upon the occasion notwithstanding there has been for years cause why all who knew and loved him should wish for his deliverance 189 130 <\s>
<s> tropical scenery grace darling southey c letter to lieutenant general sir wm <\s>
<s> gomm 190 187 memoirs ii <\s>
<s> 188 extract of letter to john peace esq dec <\s>
<s> 12 1842 ibid ii <\s>
<s> 189 extract of letter to nephew march 22 1843 ibid ii <\s>
<s> 190 the venerable and illustrious soldier has only very recently died <\s>
<s> i am rather afraid i own of any attempt of this kind notwithstanding my high opinion of his ability but if he keeps in his present mind which i doubt it will be in vain to oppose his inclination <\s>
<s> he is a great enthusiast possessed also of a most active intellect but he wants that submissive and steady good sense which is absolutely necessary for the adequate development of power in that art to which he is attached <\s>
<s> as i am on the subject of painting it may be worth while to add that pickersgill came down last summer to paint a portrait of me for sir robert peel's gallery at drayton manor <\s>
<s> it was generally thought here that this work was more successful than the one he painted some years ago for st <\s>
<s> john's college at the request of the master and fellows 177 177 memoirs ii <\s>
<s> of peace's apology for cathedrals i have no especial reason for writing at this moment of time but i have long wished to thank you for the apology for cathedrals which i have learned is from your pen <\s>
<s> the little work does you great credit it is full of that wisdom which the heart and imagination alone could adequately supply for such a subject and is moreover very pleasingly diversified by styles of treatment all good in their kind <\s>
<s> i need add no more than that i entirely concur in the views you take but what avails it <\s>
<s> the mischief is done and they who have been most prominent in setting it on foot will have to repent of their narrow comprehension which however is no satisfaction to us who from the first foresaw the evil tendency of the measure 178 178 extract of letter to john peace esq jan <\s>
<s> 19 1841 memoirs ii <\s>
<s> of the task of cowper and shenstone <\s>
<s> though i can make but little use of my eyes in writing or reading i have lately been reading cowper's task aloud and in so doing was tempted to look over the parallelisms for which mr <\s>
<s> southey was in his edition indebted to you <\s>

<s> the germ of the main thought is to be found in horace nempe inter varias nutritur sylva columnas laudaturque domus longos quae prospicit agros naturam expellas furc ?? tamen usque recurret <\s>

<s> i care comparatively little about the matter provided due care has been taken for its preservation and in his native country <\s>
<s> it would be a sad pity if the late owner's intention of sending it to america be fulfilled <\s>
<s> it is the only likeness of the great original that ever gave me the least pleasure and it is in fact most happily executed as every one who has a distinct remembrance of what c <\s>
<s> was at that time must with delight acknowledge and would be glad to certify 188 129 <\s>
<s> the papers will have informed you before you receive this of poor dear southey's decease <\s>
<s> he died yesterday morning about nine o'clock <\s>
<s> some little time since he was seized with typhus fever but he passed away without any outward signs of pain as gently as possible <\s>
<s> we are of course not without sadness upon the occasion notwithstanding there has been for years cause why all who knew and loved him should wish for his deliverance 189 130 <\s>
<s> tropical scenery grace darling southey c letter to lieutenant general sir wm <\s>
<s> gomm 190 187 memoirs ii <\s>
<s> 188 extract of letter to john peace esq dec <\s>
<s> 12 1842 ibid ii <\s>
<s> 189 extract of letter to nephew march 22 1843 ibid ii <\s>
<s> 190 the venerable and illustrious soldier has only very recently died <\s>
<s> i am rather afraid i own of any attempt of this kind notwithstanding my high opinion of his ability but if he keeps in his present mind which i doubt it will be in vain to oppose his inclination <\s>
<s> he is a great enthusiast possessed also of a most active intellect but he wants that submissive and steady good sense which is absolutely necessary for the adequate development of power in that art to which he is attached <\s>
<s> as i am on the subject of painting it may be worth while to add that pickersgill came down last summer to paint a portrait of me for sir robert peel's gallery at drayton manor <\s>
<s> it was generally thought here that this work was more successful than the one he painted some years ago for st <\s>
<s> john's college at the request of the master and fellows 177 177 memoirs ii <\s>
<s> of peace's apology for cathedrals i have no especial reason for writing at this moment of time but i have long wished to thank you for the apology for cathedrals which i have learned is from your pen <\s>
<s> the little work does you great credit it is full of that wisdom which the heart and imagination alone could adequately supply for such a subject and is moreover very pleasingly diversified by styles of treatment all good in their kind <\s>
<s> i need add no more than that i entirely concur in the views you take but what avails it <\s>
<s> the mischief is done and they who have been most prominent in setting it on foot will have to repent of their narrow comprehension which however is no satisfaction to us who from the first foresaw the evil tendency of the measure 178 178 extract of letter to john peace esq jan <\s>
<s> 19 1841 memoirs ii <\s>
<s> of the task of cowper and shenstone <\s>
<s> though i can make but little use of my eyes in writing or reading i have lately been reading cowper's task aloud and in so doing was tempted to look over the parallelisms for which mr <\s>
<s> southey was in his edition indebted to you <\s>
<s> knowing how comprehensive your acquaintance with poetry is i was rather surprised that you did not notice the identity of the thought and accompanying illustrations of it in a passage of shenstone's ode upon rural elegance compared with one in the task where cowper speaks of the inextinguishable love of the country as manifested by the inhabitants of cities in their culture of plants and flowers where the want of air cleanliness and light is so unfavourable to their growth and beauty <\s>
<s> the germ of the main thought is to be found in horace nempe inter varias nutritur sylva columnas laudaturque domus longos quae prospicit agros naturam expellas furc ?? tamen usque recurret <\s>
<s> pray write to me soon <\s>
<s> ever my dear friend faithfully your obliged wm <\s>
<s> letter to john peace esq <\s>
<s> 12 north parade bath april 19 <\s>
<s> peace here i am and have been since last wednesday evening <\s>
<s> i came down the wye and passed through bristol but arriving there at the moment the railway train was about to set off and being in the company of four ladies miss fenwick and mrs <\s>
<s> wordsworth and my daughter and niece i had not a moment to spare so could not call on you my good friend which i truly regretted <\s>
<s> pray spare an hour or two to come here and then we can fix a day when along with my daughter i can visit bristol see you mr <\s>
<s> all unite in kindest regards <\s>
<s> peace this morning my dear daughter was married in st <\s>
<s> james's in this place <\s>
<s> tomorrow we leave bath for wells and thence to the old haunts of mr <\s>
<s> coleridge and myself and dear sister about alfoxden <\s>
<s> w 181 179 extract of letter to john peace esq january 19 1841 memoirs ii <\s>
<s> 180 memoirs ii 377 <\s>
<s> letters to his brother <\s>
<s> wordsworth master of trinity college cambridge <\s>
<s> my dear brother your affectionate and generous kindness to your i trust deserving niece has quite overpowered me and her mother to whom i could not forbear communicating the contents of your letter <\s>
<s> the above relates to an act of kindness which the late master of trinity had the happiness of performing on the occasion of dora wordsworth's marriage <\s>
<s> the following refers to a serious accident which occurred to him at cambridge by a fall from his horse feb <\s>
<s> my dear brother the good accounts which we receive from time to time of your progress towards perfect recovery from your late severe accident embolden me to congratulate you in my own name and the whole of my family <\s>
<s> it remains now for us to join heartily as we all do in expressing a wish that being convalescent you would not be tempted to over exert yourself <\s>
<s> i need scarcely add that we all unite with you and your sons with susan and your other relations and all your friends in fervent thanks to almighty god for his goodness in preserving you <\s>
<s> as a brother i feel deeply and regarding your life as most valuable to the community i the more rejoice in the prospect of your life being prolonged <\s>
<s> believe me my dear brother most affectionately yours wm <\s>
<s> wordsworth 182 182 memoirs ii <\s>
<s> episcopal church of america emerson and carlyle <\s>
<s> rydal mount ambleside aug <\s>
<s> reed i have lately had the pleasure of seeing both in london and at my own house the bishop of new jersey <\s>
<s> he is a man of no ordinary powers of mind and attainments of warm feelings and sincere piety <\s>
<s> indeed i never saw a person of your country which is remarkable for cordiality whose manner was so thoroughly cordial <\s>
<s> he had been greatly delighted with his reception in england and what he had seen of it both in art and nature <\s>
<s> by the by i heard him preach an excellent sermon in london <\s>
<s> i believe this privilege is of modern date <\s>
<s> the bishop has furnished me with his funeral sermon upon bishop white to assist me in fulfilling a request which you first made to me viz <\s>
<s> that i would add a sonnet to my ecclesiastical series upon the union of the two episcopal churches of england and america 183 i will endeavour to do so when i have more leisure than at present this being the season when our beautiful region attracts many strangers who take up much of my time <\s>
<s> do you know miss peabody of boston <\s>
<s> she has just sent me with the highest eulogy certain essays of mr <\s>
<s> carlyle and he appear to be what the french used to call esprits forts though the french idols showed their spirit after a somewhat different fashion <\s>
<s> our two present philosophes who have taken a language which they suppose to be english for their vehicle are verily par nobile fratrum and it is a pity that the weakness of our age has not left them exclusively to this appropriate reward mutual admiration <\s>
<s> where is the thing which now passes for philosophy at boston to stop <\s>
<s> ever faithfully yours wm <\s>
<s> wordsworth 184 183 dr <\s>
<s> seabury was consecrated bishop of connecticut by scottish bishops at aberdeen on 14th november 1784 <\s>
<s> provoost were consecrated bishops of new york and pennsylvania at lambeth 4th february 1787 <\s>
<s> letter to john peace esq <\s>
<s> my dear peace mrs <\s>
<s> we were three months and as many weeks absent before we reached our own home again <\s>
<s> we made a very agreeable tour in devonshire going by exeter to plymouth and returning along the coast by salisbury and winchester to london <\s>
<s> in london and its neighbourhood we stayed not quite a month <\s>
<s> during this tour we visited my old haunts at and about alfoxden and nethertowey and at coleorton where we stayed several days <\s>
<s> these were farewell visits for life and of course not a little interesting .... <\s>
<s> ever faithfully yours w <\s>
<s> in the summer of 1842 wordsworth resigned his office of stamp distributor not however on a retiring pension as has been sometimes asserted <\s>
<s> in a letter dated march 2 1840 and addressed to lord morpeth he says i never did seek or accept a pension from the present or any other administration directly or indirectly <\s>
<s> but the duties and also the emoluments of the distributorship were transferred to his son william who had for some time acted as his deputy at carlisle 186 127 <\s>
<s> the master of trinity <\s>
<s> letter to a nephew <\s>
<s> my dear c your father left us yesterday having been just a week under our roof <\s>
<s> the weather was favourable and he seemed to enjoy himself much <\s>
<s> his muscular strength as proved by the walks we took together is great <\s>
<s> one day we were nearly four hours on foot without resting and he did not appear in the least fatigued <\s>
<s> we all thought him looking well and his mind appears as active as ever <\s>
<s> it was a great delight to us to see him here <\s>
<s> he was anxious to see charles he will reach winchester this afternoon i hope without injury <\s>
<s> of alston's portrait of coleridge <\s>
<s> from his own modest merits and his long connection with mr <\s>
<s> coleridge and with my early bristol remembrances he was to me an interesting person <\s>
<s> his desire to have my address must have risen i think from a wish to communicate with me upon the subject of mr <\s>
<s> alston's valuable portrait of coleridge <\s>
<s> pray tell me what has or is likely to become of it <\s>
<s> i care comparatively little about the matter provided due care has been taken for its preservation and in his native country <\s>
<s> it would be a sad pity if the late owner's intention of sending it to america be fulfilled <\s>
<s> it is the only likeness of the great original that ever gave me the least pleasure and it is in fact most happily executed as every one who has a distinct remembrance of what c <\s>
<s> was at that time must with delight acknowledge and would be glad to certify 188 129 <\s>
<s> the papers will have informed you before you receive this of poor dear southey's decease <\s>
<s> he died yesterday morning about nine o'clock <\s>
<s> some little time since he was seized with typhus fever but he passed away without any outward signs of pain as gently as possible <\s>
<s> we are of course not without sadness upon the occasion notwithstanding there has been for years cause why all who knew and loved him should wish for his deliverance 189 130 <\s>
<s> tropical scenery grace darling southey c letter to lieutenant general sir wm <\s>

<s> he is a great enthusiast possessed also of a most active intellect but he wants that submissive and steady good sense which is absolutely necessary for the adequate development of power in that art to which he is attached <\s>
<s> as i am on the subject of painting it may be worth while to add that pickersgill came down last summer to paint a portrait of me for sir robert peel's gallery at drayton manor <\s>
<s> it was generally thought here that this work was more successful than the one he painted some years ago for st <\s>

<s> our two present philosophes who have taken a language which they suppose to be english for their vehicle are verily par nobile fratrum and it is a pity that the weakness of our age has not left them exclusively to this appropriate reward mutual admiration <\s>
<s> where is the thing which now passes for philosophy at boston to stop <\s>
<s> ever faithfully yours wm <\s>
<s> wordsworth 184 183 dr <\s>
<s> seabury was consecrated bishop of connecticut by scottish bishops at aberdeen on 14th november 1784 <\s>
<s> provoost were consecrated bishops of new york and pennsylvania at lambeth 4th february 1787 <\s>
<s> letter to john peace esq <\s>
<s> my dear peace mrs <\s>
<s> we were three months and as many weeks absent before we reached our own home again <\s>
<s> we made a very agreeable tour in devonshire going by exeter to plymouth and returning along the coast by salisbury and winchester to london <\s>
<s> in london and its neighbourhood we stayed not quite a month <\s>
<s> during this tour we visited my old haunts at and about alfoxden and nethertowey and at coleorton where we stayed several days <\s>
<s> these were farewell visits for life and of course not a little interesting .... <\s>
<s> ever faithfully yours w <\s>
<s> in the summer of 1842 wordsworth resigned his office of stamp distributor not however on a retiring pension as has been sometimes asserted <\s>
<s> in a letter dated march 2 1840 and addressed to lord morpeth he says i never did seek or accept a pension from the present or any other administration directly or indirectly <\s>
<s> but the duties and also the emoluments of the distributorship were transferred to his son william who had for some time acted as his deputy at carlisle 186 127 <\s>
<s> the master of trinity <\s>
<s> letter to a nephew <\s>
<s> my dear c your father left us yesterday having been just a week under our roof <\s>
<s> the weather was favourable and he seemed to enjoy himself much <\s>
<s> his muscular strength as proved by the walks we took together is great <\s>
<s> one day we were nearly four hours on foot without resting and he did not appear in the least fatigued <\s>
<s> we all thought him looking well and his mind appears as active as ever <\s>
<s> it was a great delight to us to see him here <\s>
<s> he was anxious to see charles he will reach winchester this afternoon i hope without injury <\s>
<s> of alston's portrait of coleridge <\s>
<s> from his own modest merits and his long connection with mr <\s>
<s> coleridge and with my early bristol remembrances he was to me an interesting person <\s>
<s> his desire to have my address must have risen i think from a wish to communicate with me upon the subject of mr <\s>
<s> alston's valuable portrait of coleridge <\s>
<s> pray tell me what has or is likely to become of it <\s>
<s> i care comparatively little about the matter provided due care has been taken for its preservation and in his native country <\s>
<s> it would be a sad pity if the late owner's intention of sending it to america be fulfilled <\s>
<s> it is the only likeness of the great original that ever gave me the least pleasure and it is in fact most happily executed as every one who has a distinct remembrance of what c <\s>
<s> was at that time must with delight acknowledge and would be glad to certify 188 129 <\s>
<s> the papers will have informed you before you receive this of poor dear southey's decease <\s>
<s> he died yesterday morning about nine o'clock <\s>
<s> some little time since he was seized with typhus fever but he passed away without any outward signs of pain as gently as possible <\s>
<s> we are of course not without sadness upon the occasion notwithstanding there has been for years cause why all who knew and loved him should wish for his deliverance 189 130 <\s>
<s> tropical scenery grace darling southey c letter to lieutenant general sir wm <\s>
<s> gomm 190 187 memoirs ii <\s>
<s> 188 extract of letter to john peace esq dec <\s>
<s> 12 1842 ibid ii <\s>
<s> 189 extract of letter to nephew march 22 1843 ibid ii <\s>
<s> 190 the venerable and illustrious soldier has only very recently died <\s>
<s> i am rather afraid i own of any attempt of this kind notwithstanding my high opinion of his ability but if he keeps in his present mind which i doubt it will be in vain to oppose his inclination <\s>
<s> he is a great enthusiast possessed also of a most active intellect but he wants that submissive and steady good sense which is absolutely necessary for the adequate development of power in that art to which he is attached <\s>
<s> as i am on the subject of painting it may be worth while to add that pickersgill came down last summer to paint a portrait of me for sir robert peel's gallery at drayton manor <\s>
<s> it was generally thought here that this work was more successful than the one he painted some years ago for st <\s>
<s> john's college at the request of the master and fellows 177 177 memoirs ii <\s>
<s> of peace's apology for cathedrals i have no especial reason for writing at this moment of time but i have long wished to thank you for the apology for cathedrals which i have learned is from your pen <\s>
<s> the little work does you great credit it is full of that wisdom which the heart and imagination alone could adequately supply for such a subject and is moreover very pleasingly diversified by styles of treatment all good in their kind <\s>
<s> i need add no more than that i entirely concur in the views you take but what avails it <\s>
<s> the mischief is done and they who have been most prominent in setting it on foot will have to repent of their narrow comprehension which however is no satisfaction to us who from the first foresaw the evil tendency of the measure 178 178 extract of letter to john peace esq jan <\s>
<s> 19 1841 memoirs ii <\s>
<s> of the task of cowper and shenstone <\s>
<s> though i can make but little use of my eyes in writing or reading i have lately been reading cowper's task aloud and in so doing was tempted to look over the parallelisms for which mr <\s>
<s> southey was in his edition indebted to you <\s>
<s> knowing how comprehensive your acquaintance with poetry is i was rather surprised that you did not notice the identity of the thought and accompanying illustrations of it in a passage of shenstone's ode upon rural elegance compared with one in the task where cowper speaks of the inextinguishable love of the country as manifested by the inhabitants of cities in their culture of plants and flowers where the want of air cleanliness and light is so unfavourable to their growth and beauty <\s>
<s> the germ of the main thought is to be found in horace nempe inter varias nutritur sylva columnas laudaturque domus longos quae prospicit agros naturam expellas furc ?? tamen usque recurret <\s>
<s> pray write to me soon <\s>
<s> ever my dear friend faithfully your obliged wm <\s>
<s> letter to john peace esq <\s>
<s> 12 north parade bath april 19 <\s>
<s> peace here i am and have been since last wednesday evening <\s>
<s> i came down the wye and passed through bristol but arriving there at the moment the railway train was about to set off and being in the company of four ladies miss fenwick and mrs <\s>
<s> wordsworth and my daughter and niece i had not a moment to spare so could not call on you my good friend which i truly regretted <\s>
<s> pray spare an hour or two to come here and then we can fix a day when along with my daughter i can visit bristol see you mr <\s>
<s> all unite in kindest regards <\s>
<s> peace this morning my dear daughter was married in st <\s>
<s> james's in this place <\s>
<s> tomorrow we leave bath for wells and thence to the old haunts of mr <\s>
<s> coleridge and myself and dear sister about alfoxden <\s>
<s> w 181 179 extract of letter to john peace esq january 19 1841 memoirs ii <\s>
<s> 180 memoirs ii 377 <\s>
<s> letters to his brother <\s>
<s> wordsworth master of trinity college cambridge <\s>
<s> my dear brother your affectionate and generous kindness to your i trust deserving niece has quite overpowered me and her mother to whom i could not forbear communicating the contents of your letter <\s>
<s> the above relates to an act of kindness which the late master of trinity had the happiness of performing on the occasion of dora wordsworth's marriage <\s>
<s> the following refers to a serious accident which occurred to him at cambridge by a fall from his horse feb <\s>
<s> my dear brother the good accounts which we receive from time to time of your progress towards perfect recovery from your late severe accident embolden me to congratulate you in my own name and the whole of my family <\s>
<s> it remains now for us to join heartily as we all do in expressing a wish that being convalescent you would not be tempted to over exert yourself <\s>
<s> i need scarcely add that we all unite with you and your sons with susan and your other relations and all your friends in fervent thanks to almighty god for his goodness in preserving you <\s>
<s> as a brother i feel deeply and regarding your life as most valuable to the community i the more rejoice in the prospect of your life being prolonged <\s>
<s> believe me my dear brother most affectionately yours wm <\s>
<s> wordsworth 182 182 memoirs ii <\s>
<s> episcopal church of america emerson and carlyle <\s>
<s> rydal mount ambleside aug <\s>
<s> reed i have lately had the pleasure of seeing both in london and at my own house the bishop of new jersey <\s>
<s> he is a man of no ordinary powers of mind and attainments of warm feelings and sincere piety <\s>
<s> indeed i never saw a person of your country which is remarkable for cordiality whose manner was so thoroughly cordial <\s>
<s> he had been greatly delighted with his reception in england and what he had seen of it both in art and nature <\s>
<s> by the by i heard him preach an excellent sermon in london <\s>
<s> i believe this privilege is of modern date <\s>
<s> the bishop has furnished me with his funeral sermon upon bishop white to assist me in fulfilling a request which you first made to me viz <\s>
<s> that i would add a sonnet to my ecclesiastical series upon the union of the two episcopal churches of england and america 183 i will endeavour to do so when i have more leisure than at present this being the season when our beautiful region attracts many strangers who take up much of my time <\s>
<s> do you know miss peabody of boston <\s>
<s> she has just sent me with the highest eulogy certain essays of mr <\s>
<s> carlyle and he appear to be what the french used to call esprits forts though the french idols showed their spirit after a somewhat different fashion <\s>
<s> our two present philosophes who have taken a language which they suppose to be english for their vehicle are verily par nobile fratrum and it is a pity that the weakness of our age has not left them exclusively to this appropriate reward mutual admiration <\s>
<s> where is the thing which now passes for philosophy at boston to stop <\s>
<s> ever faithfully yours wm <\s>

<s> letters to his brother <\s>
<s> wordsworth master of trinity college cambridge <\s>
<s> my dear brother your affectionate and generous kindness to your i trust deserving niece has quite overpowered me and her mother to whom i could not forbear communicating the contents of your letter <\s>
<s> the above relates to an act of kindness which the late master of trinity had the happiness of performing on the occasion of dora wordsworth's marriage <\s>
<s> the following refers to a serious accident which occurred to him at cambridge by a fall from his horse feb <\s>
<s> my dear brother the good accounts which we receive from time to time of your progress towards perfect recovery from your late severe accident embolden me to congratulate you in my own name and the whole of my family <\s>
<s> it remains now for us to join heartily as we all do in expressing a wish that being convalescent you would not be tempted to over exert yourself <\s>
<s> i need scarcely add that we all unite with you and your sons with susan and your other relations and all your friends in fervent thanks to almighty god for his goodness in preserving you <\s>
<s> as a brother i feel deeply and regarding your life as most valuable to the community i the more rejoice in the prospect of your life being prolonged <\s>
<s> believe me my dear brother most affectionately yours wm <\s>
<s> wordsworth 182 182 memoirs ii <\s>
<s> episcopal church of america emerson and carlyle <\s>
<s> rydal mount ambleside aug <\s>
<s> reed i have lately had the pleasure of seeing both in london and at my own house the bishop of new jersey <\s>
<s> he is a man of no ordinary powers of mind and attainments of warm feelings and sincere piety <\s>
<s> indeed i never saw a person of your country which is remarkable for cordiality whose manner was so thoroughly cordial <\s>
<s> he had been greatly delighted with his reception in england and what he had seen of it both in art and nature <\s>
<s> by the by i heard him preach an excellent sermon in london <\s>
<s> i believe this privilege is of modern date <\s>
<s> the bishop has furnished me with his funeral sermon upon bishop white to assist me in fulfilling a request which you first made to me viz <\s>
<s> that i would add a sonnet to my ecclesiastical series upon the union of the two episcopal churches of england and america 183 i will endeavour to do so when i have more leisure than at present this being the season when our beautiful region attracts many strangers who take up much of my time <\s>
<s> do you know miss peabody of boston <\s>
<s> she has just sent me with the highest eulogy certain essays of mr <\s>
<s> carlyle and he appear to be what the french used to call esprits forts though the french idols showed their spirit after a somewhat different fashion <\s>
<s> our two present philosophes who have taken a language which they suppose to be english for their vehicle are verily par nobile fratrum and it is a pity that the weakness of our age has not left them exclusively to this appropriate reward mutual admiration <\s>
<s> where is the thing which now passes for philosophy at boston to stop <\s>
<s> ever faithfully yours wm <\s>
<s> wordsworth 184 183 dr <\s>
<s> seabury was consecrated bishop of connecticut by scottish bishops at aberdeen on 14th november 1784 <\s>
<s> provoost were consecrated bishops of new york and pennsylvania at lambeth 4th february 1787 <\s>
<s> letter to john peace esq <\s>
<s> my dear peace mrs <\s>
<s> we were three months and as many weeks absent before we reached our own home again <\s>
<s> we made a very agreeable tour in devonshire going by exeter to plymouth and returning along the coast by salisbury and winchester to london <\s>
<s> in london and its neighbourhood we stayed not quite a month <\s>
<s> during this tour we visited my old haunts at and about alfoxden and nethertowey and at coleorton where we stayed several days <\s>
<s> these were farewell visits for life and of course not a little interesting .... <\s>
<s> ever faithfully yours w <\s>
<s> in the summer of 1842 wordsworth resigned his office of stamp distributor not however on a retiring pension as has been sometimes asserted <\s>
<s> in a letter dated march 2 1840 and addressed to lord morpeth he says i never did seek or accept a pension from the present or any other administration directly or indirectly <\s>
<s> but the duties and also the emoluments of the distributorship were transferred to his son william who had for some time acted as his deputy at carlisle 186 127 <\s>
<s> the master of trinity <\s>
<s> letter to a nephew <\s>
<s> my dear c your father left us yesterday having been just a week under our roof <\s>
<s> the weather was favourable and he seemed to enjoy himself much <\s>
<s> his muscular strength as proved by the walks we took together is great <\s>
<s> one day we were nearly four hours on foot without resting and he did not appear in the least fatigued <\s>
<s> we all thought him looking well and his mind appears as active as ever <\s>
<s> it was a great delight to us to see him here <\s>
<s> he was anxious to see charles he will reach winchester this afternoon i hope without injury <\s>
<s> of alston's portrait of coleridge <\s>
<s> from his own modest merits and his long connection with mr <\s>
<s> coleridge and with my early bristol remembrances he was to me an interesting person <\s>
<s> his desire to have my address must have risen i think from a wish to communicate with me upon the subject of mr <\s>
<s> alston's valuable portrait of coleridge <\s>
<s> pray tell me what has or is likely to become of it <\s>
<s> i care comparatively little about the matter provided due care has been taken for its preservation and in his native country <\s>
<s> it would be a sad pity if the late owner's intention of sending it to america be fulfilled <\s>
<s> it is the only likeness of the great original that ever gave me the least pleasure and it is in fact most happily executed as every one who has a distinct remembrance of what c <\s>
<s> was at that time must with delight acknowledge and would be glad to certify 188 129 <\s>
<s> the papers will have informed you before you receive this of poor dear southey's decease <\s>
<s> he died yesterday morning about nine o'clock <\s>
<s> some little time since he was seized with typhus fever but he passed away without any outward signs of pain as gently as possible <\s>
<s> we are of course not without sadness upon the occasion notwithstanding there has been for years cause why all who knew and loved him should wish for his deliverance 189 130 <\s>
<s> tropical scenery grace darling southey c letter to lieutenant general sir wm <\s>
<s> gomm 190 187 memoirs ii <\s>
<s> 188 extract of letter to john peace esq dec <\s>
<s> 12 1842 ibid ii <\s>
<s> 189 extract of letter to nephew march 22 1843 ibid ii <\s>
<s> 190 the venerable and illustrious soldier has only very recently died <\s>
<s> i am rather afraid i own of any attempt of this kind notwithstanding my high opinion of his ability but if he keeps in his present mind which i doubt it will be in vain to oppose his inclination <\s>
<s> he is a great enthusiast possessed also of a most active intellect but he wants that submissive and steady good sense which is absolutely necessary for the adequate development of power in that art to which he is attached <\s>
<s> as i am on the subject of painting it may be worth while to add that pickersgill came down last summer to paint a portrait of me for sir robert peel's gallery at drayton manor <\s>
<s> it was generally thought here that this work was more successful than the one he painted some years ago for st <\s>
<s> john's college at the request of the master and fellows 177 177 memoirs ii <\s>
<s> of peace's apology for cathedrals i have no especial reason for writing at this moment of time but i have long wished to thank you for the apology for cathedrals which i have learned is from your pen <\s>
<s> the little work does you great credit it is full of that wisdom which the heart and imagination alone could adequately supply for such a subject and is moreover very pleasingly diversified by styles of treatment all good in their kind <\s>
<s> i need add no more than that i entirely concur in the views you take but what avails it <\s>
<s> the mischief is done and they who have been most prominent in setting it on foot will have to repent of their narrow comprehension which however is no satisfaction to us who from the first foresaw the evil tendency of the measure 178 178 extract of letter to john peace esq jan <\s>
<s> 19 1841 memoirs ii <\s>
<s> of the task of cowper and shenstone <\s>
<s> though i can make but little use of my eyes in writing or reading i have lately been reading cowper's task aloud and in so doing was tempted to look over the parallelisms for which mr <\s>
<s> southey was in his edition indebted to you <\s>
<s> knowing how comprehensive your acquaintance with poetry is i was rather surprised that you did not notice the identity of the thought and accompanying illustrations of it in a passage of shenstone's ode upon rural elegance compared with one in the task where cowper speaks of the inextinguishable love of the country as manifested by the inhabitants of cities in their culture of plants and flowers where the want of air cleanliness and light is so unfavourable to their growth and beauty <\s>
<s> the germ of the main thought is to be found in horace nempe inter varias nutritur sylva columnas laudaturque domus longos quae prospicit agros naturam expellas furc ?? tamen usque recurret <\s>
<s> pray write to me soon <\s>
<s> ever my dear friend faithfully your obliged wm <\s>
<s> letter to john peace esq <\s>
<s> 12 north parade bath april 19 <\s>
<s> peace here i am and have been since last wednesday evening <\s>
<s> i came down the wye and passed through bristol but arriving there at the moment the railway train was about to set off and being in the company of four ladies miss fenwick and mrs <\s>
<s> wordsworth and my daughter and niece i had not a moment to spare so could not call on you my good friend which i truly regretted <\s>
<s> pray spare an hour or two to come here and then we can fix a day when along with my daughter i can visit bristol see you mr <\s>
<s> all unite in kindest regards <\s>
<s> peace this morning my dear daughter was married in st <\s>
<s> james's in this place <\s>
<s> tomorrow we leave bath for wells and thence to the old haunts of mr <\s>
<s> coleridge and myself and dear sister about alfoxden <\s>
<s> w 181 179 extract of letter to john peace esq january 19 1841 memoirs ii <\s>
<s> 180 memoirs ii 377 <\s>
<s> letters to his brother <\s>
<s> wordsworth master of trinity college cambridge <\s>
<s> my dear brother your affectionate and generous kindness to your i trust deserving niece has quite overpowered me and her mother to whom i could not forbear communicating the contents of your letter <\s>
<s> the above relates to an act of kindness which the late master of trinity had the happiness of performing on the occasion of dora wordsworth's marriage <\s>
<s> the following refers to a serious accident which occurred to him at cambridge by a fall from his horse feb <\s>
<s> my dear brother the good accounts which we receive from time to time of your progress towards perfect recovery from your late severe accident embolden me to congratulate you in my own name and the whole of my family <\s>
<s> it remains now for us to join heartily as we all do in expressing a wish that being convalescent you would not be tempted to over exert yourself <\s>
<s> i need scarcely add that we all unite with you and your sons with susan and your other relations and all your friends in fervent thanks to almighty god for his goodness in preserving you <\s>
<s> as a brother i feel deeply and regarding your life as most valuable to the community i the more rejoice in the prospect of your life being prolonged <\s>
<s> believe me my dear brother most affectionately yours wm <\s>
<s> wordsworth 182 182 memoirs ii <\s>
<s> episcopal church of america emerson and carlyle <\s>
<s> rydal mount ambleside aug <\s>
<s> reed i have lately had the pleasure of seeing both in london and at my own house the bishop of new jersey <\s>
<s> he is a man of no ordinary powers of mind and attainments of warm feelings and sincere piety <\s>
<s> indeed i never saw a person of your country which is remarkable for cordiality whose manner was so thoroughly cordial <\s>
<s> he had been greatly delighted with his reception in england and what he had seen of it both in art and nature <\s>
<s> by the by i heard him preach an excellent sermon in london <\s>
<s> i believe this privilege is of modern date <\s>
<s> the bishop has furnished me with his funeral sermon upon bishop white to assist me in fulfilling a request which you first made to me viz <\s>
<s> that i would add a sonnet to my ecclesiastical series upon the union of the two episcopal churches of england and america 183 i will endeavour to do so when i have more leisure than at present this being the season when our beautiful region attracts many strangers who take up much of my time <\s>
<s> do you know miss peabody of boston <\s>
<s> she has just sent me with the highest eulogy certain essays of mr <\s>
<s> carlyle and he appear to be what the french used to call esprits forts though the french idols showed their spirit after a somewhat different fashion <\s>
<s> our two present philosophes who have taken a language which they suppose to be english for their vehicle are verily par nobile fratrum and it is a pity that the weakness of our age has not left them exclusively to this appropriate reward mutual admiration <\s>
<s> where is the thing which now passes for philosophy at boston to stop <\s>
<s> ever faithfully yours wm <\s>
<s> wordsworth 184 183 dr <\s>
<s> seabury was consecrated bishop of connecticut by scottish bishops at aberdeen on 14th november 1784 <\s>
<s> provoost were consecrated bishops of new york and pennsylvania at lambeth 4th february 1787 <\s>
<s> letter to john peace esq <\s>
<s> my dear peace mrs <\s>
<s> we were three months and as many weeks absent before we reached our own home again <\s>
<s> we made a very agreeable tour in devonshire going by exeter to plymouth and returning along the coast by salisbury and winchester to london <\s>
<s> in london and its neighbourhood we stayed not quite a month <\s>
<s> during this tour we visited my old haunts at and about alfoxden and nethertowey and at coleorton where we stayed several days <\s>
<s> these were farewell visits for life and of course not a little interesting .... <\s>
<s> ever faithfully yours w <\s>
<s> in the summer of 1842 wordsworth resigned his office of stamp distributor not however on a retiring pension as has been sometimes asserted <\s>
<s> in a letter dated march 2 1840 and addressed to lord morpeth he says i never did seek or accept a pension from the present or any other administration directly or indirectly <\s>
<s> but the duties and also the emoluments of the distributorship were transferred to his son william who had for some time acted as his deputy at carlisle 186 127 <\s>
<s> the master of trinity <\s>
<s> letter to a nephew <\s>
<s> my dear c your father left us yesterday having been just a week under our roof <\s>
<s> the weather was favourable and he seemed to enjoy himself much <\s>
<s> his muscular strength as proved by the walks we took together is great <\s>
<s> one day we were nearly four hours on foot without resting and he did not appear in the least fatigued <\s>
<s> we all thought him looking well and his mind appears as active as ever <\s>
<s> it was a great delight to us to see him here <\s>
<s> he was anxious to see charles he will reach winchester this afternoon i hope without injury <\s>
<s> of alston's portrait of coleridge <\s>
<s> from his own modest merits and his long connection with mr <\s>
<s> coleridge and with my early bristol remembrances he was to me an interesting person <\s>
<s> his desire to have my address must have risen i think from a wish to communicate with me upon the subject of mr <\s>
<s> alston's valuable portrait of coleridge <\s>
<s> pray tell me what has or is likely to become of it <\s>
<s> i care comparatively little about the matter provided due care has been taken for its preservation and in his native country <\s>
<s> it would be a sad pity if the late owner's intention of sending it to america be fulfilled <\s>
<s> it is the only likeness of the great original that ever gave me the least pleasure and it is in fact most happily executed as every one who has a distinct remembrance of what c <\s>
<s> was at that time must with delight acknowledge and would be glad to certify 188 129 <\s>
<s> the papers will have informed you before you receive this of poor dear southey's decease <\s>
<s> he died yesterday morning about nine o'clock <\s>
<s> some little time since he was seized with typhus fever but he passed away without any outward signs of pain as gently as possible <\s>
<s> we are of course not without sadness upon the occasion notwithstanding there has been for years cause why all who knew and loved him should wish for his deliverance 189 130 <\s>

<s> 190 the venerable and illustrious soldier has only very recently died <\s>
<s> i am rather afraid i own of any attempt of this kind notwithstanding my high opinion of his ability but if he keeps in his present mind which i doubt it will be in vain to oppose his inclination <\s>
<s> he is a great enthusiast possessed also of a most active intellect but he wants that submissive and steady good sense which is absolutely necessary for the adequate development of power in that art to which he is attached <\s>
<s> as i am on the subject of painting it may be worth while to add that pickersgill came down last summer to paint a portrait of me for sir robert peel's gallery at drayton manor <\s>
<s> it was generally thought here that this work was more successful than the one he painted some years ago for st <\s>
<s> john's college at the request of the master and fellows 177 177 memoirs ii <\s>
<s> of peace's apology for cathedrals i have no especial reason for writing at this moment of time but i have long wished to thank you for the apology for cathedrals which i have learned is from your pen <\s>
<s> the little work does you great credit it is full of that wisdom which the heart and imagination alone could adequately supply for such a subject and is moreover very pleasingly diversified by styles of treatment all good in their kind <\s>
<s> i need add no more than that i entirely concur in the views you take but what avails it <\s>
<s> the mischief is done and they who have been most prominent in setting it on foot will have to repent of their narrow comprehension which however is no satisfaction to us who from the first foresaw the evil tendency of the measure 178 178 extract of letter to john peace esq jan <\s>
